data.title: Financial Crime Litigators Academy
data.meta_description: News posts by Fellows of The International Academy of Financial Crime Litigators
data.text:
Supreme Court of Canada rules legislators will not enact unconstitutional laws and when found to do so can be expected to pay Charter damages.

After conflicting interpretations by lower courts in the case of United States vs. Kousisis, the Supreme Court may help clarify the boundaries for conviction.

In-depth research and interviews across the shipping industry leads to a call for regulatory reform in this groundbreaking ebook.

Businesses and careers are made- and lost- by their reputation. Knowing how to safeguard yours is a vital survival skill.

As the EU continues to uphold a myriad of sanctions, every member nation and government must engage consistently to achieve their intended aims.

When dubious evidence is used to build a case, clients and firms reputations are at stake. Recent cases have become cautionary tales about the importance of due diligence in the pursuit of justice.

As Hunter Biden, son of POTUS Joe Biden, faces ongoing prosecution, it appears his celebrity has subjected him to a different set of rules from the general populace.

Whats in it for the victims when white-collar criminal prosecutions end with fines or orders to disgorge profits but without convictions?

With a history of human rights violations, this nations bid for hosting the 2034 mens championship is challenging FIFA to carry out its commitment to the dignity and worth of all.

Discover how and when to use MLATs or Letters Rogatory in the pursuit of evidence in international jurisdictions.

Press releases hold sway in the court of public opinion. Might they also impact justice in the court of law?

The time may at last be right for rapid, negotiated settlement of economic criminal proceedings.

Take a comprehensive look at the aspirations and achievements of strategies that are on the right path.

Dr. Crag Wrights claims that Nakamoto is the pseudonym under which he created bitcoin and authored the Bitcoin White Paper, but Englands High Court ruled otherwise.

Supervision and regulation of all involved parties may be a hard sell, but its vital to deter money laundering and exploitation.

SCOTUS is expected to establish precedent for defining the parameters of bribery when it hears the US v. Snyder case.

As a shift is made from corporate to greater individual accountability in financial matters, will IAF truly offer equitable solutions?

This collaborative book is hot off the press and packed with insights into current issues of negotiated justice, compliance, and protection for the accused.

Congratulations to Academic Karen Woody on her selection, and many thanks for the efforts made to preserve important capital markets documents.

What do DPAs, university students, legal culture, and federal judicial authority have in common? Theyre all in a days work for this Swiss Fellow.

This vital resource paves the way for success in international litigation and collaboration by explaining how each nation understands and applies client/ attorney confidentiality.

In the wake of FTX and Binances downfalls, the future of crypto assets depends upon the clear oversight and accountability proposed here.

While the UK moved decisively to freeze Russian assets, it now faces complications in determining avenues how and when decisions can be reversed. Navigating this changing legal landscape requires the shrewd application of laws, political savvy, and respect for individual rights.

The data reveals the battle against money laundering and terrorism financing have only just begun. On a global scale, risk scores have increased and effectiveness scores have decreased over the previous year. What does this mean for the future of money laundering, and where does litigation begin?

Even as Central Eastern Europe and South Eastern Europe expand regulations to mitigate the impact of transferred criminal, tax, or regulatory corporate liability, a burden of responsibility lies on the shoulders of would-be buyers to avoid becoming the target of litigation at individual or corporate levels.

Rapidly expanding global crypto fraud, followed by the insolvency of crypto industries, has necessitated innovative solutions and judicial orders. Faceless fraudsters and procedural complexities remain hurdles to overcome in the journey to crypto asset recovery.

In light of its successful application in the Smagin case, however, might foreigners have a new-found hope for achieving justice in US courts through Civil RICO? Wielding this weapon can come with great costs, but in the right hands, it can demolish even the most complex wealth-protection strategies.

When it comes to self-defense, nations must lean upon law and logic to guide its decisions.

Rome presents many strengths and challenges to overcome if the city hopes to become the new home of EUs Anti-Money Laundering Authority.

Updates to the US Education Departments guidelines for sexual misconduct and sex discrimination prosecution have been delayed, providing much needed time to reconsider their impact on due process.

In the US, the spotlight tends to shine on specific areas of white collar crime. In 2023, it seems prosecution efforts have shifted in light of world events.

As instructors entrenched in the corporate world, adjuncts provide students far more than lectures. Learn how to better integrate them into the universitys culture.

In this Fellow of the Month Q&A, Gary Naftalis talks about helping individuals and corporations in times of crisis.

Numerous state courts assert attorney-client privilege holds true when client seeks counsel in good faith and the attorney holds a license for practicing somewhere, even if the clients need is outside the lawyers jurisdiction.

In a highly improbable move, the Swiss court admits an unspecified claim, a decision that will expand capabilities for prosecuting white collar crime.

This latest edition emphasizes questions of demarcation, compares and contrasts Lugano and Brussels conventions, and focuses on exequatur procedure. Secure a copy of this useful reference tool.

The French Chamber of Commerce recently handed down a decision that puts new weight on the shoulders of companies to prevent and detect illegal activities.

The Department of Justice prepares to closely monitor the expenditures of the US Paycheck Protection Program, originator of $800 billion in loans during COVID-19 for potential misuse of funds.

Fellow Benjamin Gruenstein, and his colleagues Evan Norris and Daniel Barabander challenge the legal foundation of the Tornado Cash indictment by providing an insightful analysis of the Bank Secrecy Act and FinCEN's 2019 guidance, which provides a principle-based rubric for defining money transmission, with a comprehensive and understandable description of the underlying code at issue.

In this Fellow of the Month Q&A, Ilias Anagnostopoulos talks about how a crisis is a learning process that develops new skills.

If we fail to view criminal culpability through the eyes of victims, we not only deny them justice, but the equal rights and values that are the hallmarks of a democratic society as well.

What are the roles and responsibilities of business owners and employees when an investigation is taking place within their company?

Despite defendants efforts to have the case dismissed, Mozambiques Commercial Court will hold a hearing to put bribery allegations to rest.

Despite politicized rhetoric, American self defense laws do not hearken to the lore of the old west. T. Markus Funk compares US law to those of several other nations, providing needed perspective.

When it comes to asset seizure, Maria Nizerro cautions wisdom and prudence, as the implications for political, social, and moral spheres will have a global impact.

In his recent article, Markus Funk issues a challenge to media outlets to get their facts straight and present them in a clear, direct manner devoid of sensationalism, otherwise, they are contributing to the all-too-commonplace incidences of violence against trespassers.

Take a listen to Alex Jay's podcast feature on Stewarts Commercial Litigation Podcast to explain Quincecare Duty and the delicate balance of responsibility banks hold to honor the requests of their clients while preventing fraudulent activity.

The scope and impact of AML laws in Greece are thoroughly presented in a Q&A format.

Markus Funk's article delves into the complexities of self-defense law and the need for a clearer understanding of its application.

Lon Moubayed and colleagues report and evaluate the latest decisions of the Superior Court of Qubec in the case against Ultra Electronics Forensic Technology Inc.

In this article, Markus Funk, provides an insiders look at what its like to be a law schools adjunct instructor. His article raises questions about how to better integrate these professors into university life and evaluates the real value they add to the educational framework.

Jitka Logesova, known for her expertise in litigation policy, offers reflective commentary on the European Commission's recent directive, which aimed to enhance international cooperation and address enforcement loopholes but missed the inclusion of non-resolution agreements as a viable option.

Markus Funk, contributed and discusses how the ruling is viewed as a loss in the prosecution of issues that impact workers compensation and employment opportunities.

While acknowledging the impact of AI software in the legal field, Mangeat emphasizes the indispensable value of skilled lawyers. He advises professionals to continuously enhance their expertise, improve communication skills, and learn a foreign language. With this growth mindset, ChatGPT can serve as a helpful tool.

Investors responded strongly when Credit Suisse made the decision to eliminate $18 billion worth of high-risk bonds, and now Marc Hassberger and his team are representing the 120 claims being brought before the Swiss Federal Administrative Tribunal.

Jonathan Sack poses a challenging question in the New York Law Journal as well as guides readers through the new policies and their actualized- as well as potential impact with depth and discernment.

Regis Bismuth's analysis in the article focuses on the European Union's resolute efforts in imposing economic sanctions on Russia, examining their implications for dealing with hostile nations and setting new precedents.

Frederick Davis has been monitoring the Halkbank case, where the US Supreme Court ruled on April 19, 2023, that the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act (FSIA) does not provide immunity in criminal cases. The decision now rests with the US Court of Appeals to determine the possibility of acquiring common law immunity.

In this article, Nicola Bonucci delves into the proposed EU legislation on mandatory human rights due diligence, its potential impact on companies, and provides suggestions for how companies can effectively adapt to and meet the new requirements.

Grgoire Mangeat creates a profile of The "Excellent" Lawyer in an Age of #ChatGPT" in a piece for Forum du Barreau de Bruxelles.

Maria Nizerro writes on the art market being at risk of criminal infiltration and abuse due to its lack of regulation and low-priority regulatory attention.

In this Fellow of the Month Q&A, Oliver discusses how clear communication bridges the gap between relevant and irrelevant issues.

Nicola Bonucci co-authors on the OECD Working Group's call for using the Anti-Bribery Convention to fight corruption in mega-sports events like the Olympics and World Cup.

The article by Jonathan Sack examines the issue of victims' rights during the negotiation of DPAs and discusses the reforms called for by the US Department of Justice in response to the Boeing DPA establishment.

Frederick Davis highlights the key issues and evaluates what blanket immunity could mean for SOEs and the Department of Justices efforts to prosecute international crime.

The article, co-written by Jonathan Sack, assesses recent US court precedents and their implications for future cases, emphasizing the challenges of successfully prosecuting bribery and public corruption cases, especially when explicit quid pro quo must be demonstrated.

For our German readers, Gretta Fenner discusses the Basel Institute on Governance's work to return ill-gotten funds to Ukraine and how the Foreign Illicit Assets Act of 2016 can legally return seized Russian assets to Ukraine.

Nicola Bonucci and his colleagues published a report on the top 10 predicted business and human rights issues for 2023, providing insights into potential legal, regulatory, and reputational risks facing corporations across various industries.

In this Fellow of the Month Q&A, Karyn talks about her interests and shares advice with rising talent.

Regis Bismuth contributed a chapter on the ambiguity between compliance and sovereignty in the recently published The Monumental Goals of Compliance.

In this Fellow of the Month Q&A, Benjamin talks about active participation and debate amongst Fellows.

The Law Reviews published Roberto Pisano's practical overview of asset recovery rules and procedures in Italy.

Jonathan Sack together with colleagues reviews the long-term effect of the decade-long prosecution of Lawrence Hoskins and its impact in future FCPA and white-collar actions.

In this Fellow of the Month Q&A, Gabriele discusses her excitement about future collaborations and contributions to the financial crime field.

For our Portuguese speakers, Isadora Fingermann writes about how the courts face the challenge of adapting the jurisprudence to the intense technological transformations.

GIR covers Stphane Bonifassis involvement in a recent settlement with financial crime prosecutors in France

For our French speakers, Stphane Bonifassi takes on the French justice system and urges courts to streamline the litigation process and consider dispute settlements rather than expensive, inefficient lengthy trials.

Czech government takes steps to enact into law the Czech Magnitsky Act. Jitka Logesova compares this version to the U.S. Magnitsky Act and finds the former to have a much broader scope than human rights violations.

Elizabeth Ortega writes about positive steps law firms can take to improve litigators well-being in a Bloomberg Law Insight

Jonathan Sack analyses whether Congress has authorized the SEC to compel disclosure of greenhouse gas emissions data in his latest

Gretta Fenner announces Basels partnership with RISE Ukraine to promote integrity, sustainability, and efficiency as part of Ukraines post-war reconstruction

Keith Oliver explores former FIFA and UEFA leaders acquittal by a Swiss court and suggests the investigation is far from over.

Fred Davis writes about how the Fifth Circuit is analyzing various issues touching on cross-border criminal investigations.

Bruce Zagaris explains the Memorandum of Understanding on Tourism Cooperation, underscoring one of the key instruments to tourism development signed by the Chinese and Cuban governments.

Dorothy Siron writes on the cryptocurrency market wipe-out and considers looking into China as a mechanism.

In this publication, Professor Horders analysis goes beyond issues of policy and theory.

Thomas Weibel authored a piece on the decision to put an abrupt end to U.S.-style discovery in aid of arbitration proceedings.

Thank you to Fellows Jonathan Sack, Ben Gruenstein, Lucinda Low and Fred Davis for filing an amicus on behalf of The Academy in the Rafoi case.

Roberto Pisano writes on Corporate Criminal Liability in Italy by breaking down nature and requirements of corporate liability, applicable procedure, conditions to exclude or mitigate corporate liability, and applicable sanctions.

Benjamin Borsodi comments on the public interest program as Switzerland looks to seize and return funds to Ukraine.

Basels Gretta Fenner executes an agreement with the government of Bulgaria in an effort to fight corruption.

Here, Professor Horder examines and critiques UK laws while studying the right to lie principle.

Elizabeth Ortega raises awareness about mental health by outlining ways to normalize the conversation and how to address inherent stressors in the legal profession.

Elizabeth Ortega in an article for Law360, explains some best practices to avoid prematurely releasing embargoed information to the public.

This article explores whether regulatory initiatives to stringently discipline credit rating agencies activities, or other initiatives which reflect an increasing willingness to control speech in financial, are in line with relevant principles guaranteeing the freedom of expression.

Alison Cronin reviews the field of attempted legal control and regulation of delinquent conduct by business actors in the form of exploitative, collusive and corrupt behavior.

Roberto Pisano provides an overview on Bribery & Corruption Laws and Regulations for Italy's chapter 2022.

This American Bar Association guide considers the landscape and legal framework of the specific jurisdiction and provides a practical narration as to best practice in each. Saverio Lembo co-edited it.

Mark Pieth shared his views on the problematic abandonment of ships and crews which amounts to a significant violation of human rights.

Legal Business World published a Q&A featuring Co-Founders, Elizabeth Ortega and Gretta Fenner, Fellow Dorothy Siron, and Professor Jennifer Arlen at NYU, highlighting The Academy's mission and global impact.

Thank you to Fellow Jonathan Sack for filing an amicus on behalf of The Academy in the Hoskins case.

Elizabeth Ortega shares recommendations on how to network during isolation in Legal Business World.

The first in a series in a series of joint publications with the Basel Institute on Governance looks at the impact of illegal wildlife trade on business. See the perspective of Academy Fellow Antenor Madruga on this topic.

Fellows of The International Academy of Financial Crime Litigators have surveyed their respective jurisdictions to report how they are coping with the pandemic within the context of each particular situation.

Faced with a global pandemic that necessitates social distancing, Elizabeth Ortega reveals to Law360 how she's advising clients to use communications strategies to manage through these challenging times.

In Commercial Dispute Resolution's "Essential Intelligence: Fraud, Asset Tracing and Recovery", Dorothy Siron explains that Hong Kong is a hotbed for fraud and other financial, white-collar crimes, while it has developed a legal framework to assist victims seeking redress.

In an article written for Law360, Elizabeth Ortega explains how the intriguing case of former Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn uncovers a lesson for lawyers about how sound communications strategy helps manage a crisis and can, if done correctly, repair a reputation.

The workshop Legal Consequences of Corruption and Money Laundering in International Arbitration, hosted by the Basel Institute and Mark Pieth, featured the president of the ICC International Court of Arbitration Alexis Mourre, who spoke about the value of the toolkit that guides parties and arbitrators dealing with matters of corruption and money laundering.)

Elizabeth Ortega's article, featured in Legal Business World, examines the importance of defining your narrative at the onset.

Elizabeth Ortega explains in her business development article for Legal Business World how stepping away from risk-averse tendencies can inspire new approaches to tackling difficult cases the same way a song can transport you to a different time, place, or emotional state.

Writing for Legal Business World, Elizabeth Ortega shows how cleverness can often lead to short-term gain, while emotional intelligence keeps business and positivity moving forward.

Elizabeth Ortega writes in Legal Business World that leaders who discern when to speak up and when to lie low influence people and drive change.
